author: sdavid1726
body:
Sorry guys, I'm going to be the party pooper here. There are a lot of things wrong with this post. OP didn't actually make any arguments. They just posted a spreadsheet and stated some facts about the numbers with zero analysis, then slapped a clickbait title  on top. Did everyone who upvoted this just smile and nod and say "Yeah, I recognize some of those words..."?

First off, you have a lot of errors in your spreadsheet, both in data entry (e.g. a lot of the D column) and in your calculations. Why is "Total Capital Employed" = "Net Long Term Debt" + "Book Value"??? A lot of your other formulae have similar errors. Even if the data was correct, Point I still wouldn't make sense or mean anything. How can a company have "no capital in their business"? Do you know what capital *is*? You're telling me that Amazon didn't have any capital until 2012? A company can't exist without capital in the same way lemonade can't exist without lemons. Did you mean negative working capital? In that case you'd still be wrong, as Amazon's current assets have exceeded its current liabilities since at least 2004.

Point II is flat out wrong. Cash flow numbers aren't a valid measure for company growth. Comparing CapEx to D&A in the manner you described would lead you to conclude that Amazon has been "shrinking" for the past four years: https://www.macrotrends.net/stocks/charts/AMZN/amazon/cash-flow-statement?freq=A

Take a look at the balance sheet. Amazon has experienced monotonic growth as far as those tables go back.

Point III isn't really proving anything either. You're basically saying "Amazon made money". Sure, 7 years after it IPO'd. Lots of other companies made money year after year from 2004 onward, what made Amazon so special?

I'm really disappointed that this post hit the top of /r/investing. It's word salad that's trying to draw some sort of revelatory, hyperbolic conclusion. OP is far from an expert here. I recommend everybody here look at a company balance sheet + income statement (Form 10-K) and actually learn what all of the words and numbers mean. Here's a good place to start: https://corporatefinanceinstitute.com/resources/knowledge/accounting/financial-statements-example-amazon-case-study/

author: ForemanDomai
body:
Physical gold bullion is one of the few financial assets without any counter-party risk. I prefer gold ETFs for my Golden Butterfly/Permanent Portfolios, but I keep a small amount of physical metals which are much more difficult for the state or financial system to contest, it can be used as a hedge to frustrate the court's effort to reduce your wealth. Depending on your threat profile, holding physical gold in overseas storage is also useful (but introduces that counter-party risk).

People think in extremes - either the system of currency, private property, functioning legal structures that ensure liquidity and proper market access are fully functional, or we are down to guns and canned food. They can't imagine the huge gray area of misery in a failed state where, although you're not living like in Fallout, you still hope you have something other than fiat.

author: capnwally14
body:
In super simple terms:   
A short sell means borrowing a stock in order to sell it - promising the original owner you'll pay them back the original stock at a future date. Imagine Joey thinks Company A's stock is too high at $100. If he wants to short sell the Company A's stock, he could go to a broker and borrow someone else's share (in this case he could borrow Jimmy's stock) and sell it at $100 - promising to give Jimmy back his share in the future. If Joey is right, and the stock drops to $80, then he can buy back Company A's share at $80 (and give it to Jimmy) and keep $20 for himself. If on the other hand Company A's share goes up to $120, Joey is out of luck and will have to pay $120 to give back the share to Jimmy - thereby losing $20. You can see why short selling is dangerous - in this situation, Jimmy at most could have gained $100 (if Company A's price had collapsed to zero), but at most could have lost an infinite amount of money.   


So what do you do if you want to bet against a company, but don't want to short sell? You might instead consider a put option. A put option is buying the right to sell a company's stock (for a premium) at a specific price (known as the strike) on a specific date\*. So instead of short selling, maybe Joey will buy a put option that says for $1 he can buy the right to sell Company's stock for $100 in one year. If in a year the price of the stock is above $100, then the option will expire worthless - as anyone would rather sell at a higher price than at $100. If the price is below $100 in a year, then Joey will be able to exercise his option and take his earnings. Unlike selling short, now Joey is at most only losing the premium of the option, and at best earning $100.   


A call option is the opposite of a put option. A call option is buying the right to buy a stock at a given price on a future date. For $1 Joey might be able to buy the right to buy a shares of Company A for $100 in 1 year. If the shares are above $100 in a year, he'll make money, if they're below his options will expire worthless.   


Options are slightly tricky in that their value is not just comprised of the difference between share price and the exercise price, but also volatility and time value. You can read more about Black Scholes which is how options are priced elsewhere. You can also read about strategies about combining patterns of options to construct more sophisticated trades (like iron condors).

  
\* Note - European and American options are different here.

author: CanYouPleaseChill
body:
"If I had to choose a great single fallacy of investing, it's believing that when a stock's price goes up, then you've made a good investment. People often take comfort when their recent purchase of something at $5 a share goes up to $6, as if that proves the wisdom of the purchase. Nothing could be further from the truth."

- Peter Lynch


"Investors are right (and wrong) all the time for the ‘wrong reason’… the correctness of a decision can’t be judged from the outcome. Nevertheless, that’s how people assess it. A good decision is one that’s optimal at the time that it’s made, when the future is by definition unknown. Thus, correct decisions are often unsuccessful, and vice versa." 

- Howard Marks

author: apfejes
body:
I enjoy reading other people's due diligence, but the company is worth $1.8B, and has only phase 2 results completed. I started writing out a rebuttal, and then realized there was already one written for me.

[https://www.fool.com/investing/2019/11/21/why-investors-should-resist-buying-karuna-therapeu.aspx](https://www.fool.com/investing/2019/11/21/why-investors-should-resist-buying-karuna-therapeu.aspx)

In summary: 

* your timeline is wrong: Drug probably won't get to the market till 2023
* Their financials aren't bad, but P3 trials are much more expensive than P2, so expect their burn rate to rise accordingly... maybe $20-25M a quarter?  It's pretty tight to get them to commercialization.  I'd give it a fairly strong probability that they'll raise again before commercialization, post P3.
* A lot of drugs clear P2 trials, but fail to get through P3: This drug is not sufficiently de-risked to warrant the current valuation.  
* Small molecules and schizophrenia is an EXTREMELY challenging combination.  Many many people have tried, and very very few have succeeded.  
* Even wikipedia suggests that Xanomeline has a high rate of negative symptoms and side effects, which suggests that even if it gets to the end, it will be a challenge getting it through PDUFA, and the known high drop-out rate in clinical trials will be a significant challenge for a P3.

I'm not an MD, but I do have a PhD.  This is way too bullish for me, even with a small amount of DD I did in the last 20 minutes.

author: TheWizardOfFrobozz
body:
In the example you gave, there are two taxable events, both of which should be reported to the IRS:

1) Receiving the free stock. This counts are ordinary income for the market value of the stock on the day you receive it.
2) Selling the stock for a profit. This counts as a short-term or long-term capital gain (depending on how long you held it) of the amount its price increased by.

For example, suppose you received a free share of AAPL on July 30, 2019. AAPL closed at $213.04 that day, so you would report $213.04 as income. Now suppose you sold it on December 31, 2019 for $291.52. Your short-term capital gain is $291.52 - $213.04 = $78.48. Whether either of these events increases the taxes you have to pay depends on your other income, your filing status, other gains/losses, etc.

I'm thinking of writing a tax primer for Robinhood users and posting it here sometime during the next few days since there seem to be so many questions.

author: FlingingOptions
body:
As the buyer of a call, you’re buying the right to purchase those shares from somebody else at the strike price. If it crashed to $0, you’re not going to exercise your right to buy them at $325, so your contract would expire worthless. You’re only out the $33 you paid for it. 

Temper your expectations of what “unlimited” means here, though. Unlimited is technically true as there is no limit to how high a stock can go, but unless there is some major binary event that makes it skyrocket to BRK.A levels in two days, your potential profits will be much less impressive. 

With low volatility (IV is currently the lowest it’s been in the past 52 weeks), making it to your breakeven is a long shot with only two full trading days left. Even if it gets to 327 (roughly double the expected move) by the time your contract ends, you’re looking at a ballpark profit of $167. Nothing to sneeze at, for sure, but the chances are low.

Five decades and ten variants later, the MAX is a monsterized hybrid of a thing, a plane that wants, and needs to be something that it’s not: all muscle and power and advanced technology, jammed into the framework of a fifty year-old design. Call it a software failure, or call it bad corporate strategy and stubbornness.

author: Logan_Maransy
body:
I'll help you out in a non ironic way, because options are actually really simple but can seem confusing if you are looking at this screenshot with ignorance. 

OP bought 30 call contracts (+30) for $77K (equity in screen shot of $87K - the gain of $10K experienced since he bought at $77K), at an average cost of $25.78 per share (1 contract = 100 shares, so 30 contracts = 3000 shares, so the $77K checks out.)

The "Breakeven Price" is listed at $1905.78. If we subtract the cost OP spent on each contract, we find the strike price of the calls is $1880. The EXP Date (expiration date) is 1/31, or tomorrow at close. Finally, the current price ($29.23) is the "current" price of the contracts. Because option markets are open only during normal trading hours, this cost represents the last price at close and are not updated to reflect after-hours market movement. 

In summary, OP walked up to a roulette table and slapped 77 grand in cash on the "AMZN stock will be above 1905 by the end of day tomorrow". Note that is closed at 1870 today. If it's above 1905 by tomorrow, he will gain money overall. And if it's below 1905 he will lose money. If it's below 1880, he will lose ALL 77K.

AMZN absolutely fucking killed earnings, released after hours today. Straight up Trogdor Burninating the peasants type of slaughter. In after hours trading AMZN is now at 2074. OPs call options are now "in the money" which means they have intrinsic value, because they allow the owner of the contract (currently OP) to buy 3000 shares of AMZN from someone at a price of $1880, when it's clearly market valued at $2074. What a deal right?! That intrinsic value is the difference between the strike price (1880) and the market price (2074), which is $194. 

Let's say OP doesn't have the capital to buy 3000 fucking shares of AMZN ($6 mill+ now) in order to then immediately sell it for a profit. Well, that's fine, because somebody in the market absolutely does, and will buy his contracts off him for at least $194. 

Thus OP bought 30 contracts, each at a cost of $2,578 ($77K initial cost) and is going to be able to sell them tomorrow for at least $19,400 each ($582K final result). So 582K-77K initial cost = 500K+ profit, as OP stated in title. Another way to look at it is: 194/25.78 = 7.53x multiplier in one night, on a 77K bet.

author: veritasinvestments
body:
Iran and the US probably made a deal where Iran had to give up its power in the region in exchange for easing the sanctions. The price? Iran has to give up its Quds leader. In one move, Khamenei has also consolidated his own power by taking out someone who, in the past, has threatened military coups in the event of left-wing movements and relations with the US. By doing this, he has severely reduced Sepah’s power while simultaneously allowing for sanctions to be gradually eased. Most people don’t understand this, but IRGC is getting so powerful that it is actually threatening the very existence of the Iranian government as it is. Soleimani was essentially its key leader, and by giving him up, Khamenei has consolidated his power. This is what most likely has occurred. Otherwise, why did it take so long for the US to kill this guy? He’s been active in Iraq and Syria for the past decade.

Also, some IRGC hardliners wanted Soleimani to run for president. There’s an internal war between the clerics and the IRGC for power in Iran. While someone like Rouhani or Ahmadinejad could just be puppets for Khamenei, Soleimani would actually not be a puppet president. Given that Rouhani is also in his last term, if Soleimani ran, he could present as a viable candidate. The only way that Khamenei could consolidate power for the clerics was to take him out. Again, if you were in Iran right now or know about how the Iranian government works, this scenario would probably be what you would be thinking right now as well.

author: thewimsey
body:
The real question isn’t why these companies aren’t splitting; it’s why it was common in the past to split stocks.

The reason for *that* is that it used to be a requirement that you buy shares in “round lots” (i.e., in 100 share increments).  You typically couldn’t buy individual shares, much less fractional shares.  So even a price of $100 would entail a $10,000 commitment. (There were a handful of brokers who would “break lots” for an up charge...but that’s not ideal).

One of the initial advantages of mutual funds were that they allowed people to get around the “lot” requirement...the ease of diversification is still a mutual fund feature, but it was even more so when you had to buy 100 stocks at a time. 

Eventually - starting with the rise of discount brokers - this requirement became more and more relaxed, and the need to have stock prices that weren’t astronomical if multiplied by 100 disappeared.

author: InfiniteAccuracy
body: Don't even ask the question. The answer is yes, it's priced in. Think Amazon will beat the next earnings? That's already been priced in. World War III? Priced in. You work at the drive thru for Mickey D's and found out that the burgers are made of human meat? Priced in. You think insiders don't already know that? The market is an all powerful, all encompassing being that knows the very inner workings of your subconscious before you were even born. Your very existence was priced in decades ago when the market was valuing Standard Oil's expected future earnings based on population growth that would lead to your birth, what age you would get a car, how many times you would drive your car every week, how many times you take the bus/train, etc. Anything you can think of has already been priced in, even the things you aren't thinking of. You have no original thoughts. Your consciousness is just an illusion, a product of the omniscent market. Free will is a myth. The market sees all, knows all and will be there from the beginning of time until the end of the universe (the market has already priced in the heat death of the universe). So please, before you make a post on wsb asking whether AAPL has priced in earpods 11 sales or whatever, know that it has already been priced in and don't ask such a dumb fucking question again.

author: 6pounds10pence
body:
Wife's father died, left lots of money, no financial planning, mother in law goes crazy, gives away 1.4 million to scammers over 5 insane years, suddenly I have to figure out how to save a house, retirement and a person from the brink. I have a friend whom is a financial advisor, learn a lot from him, got interested in what he does, applied to be an advisor, got the job, got paid to study, state life and health, series 7 and 66, lots of training and tools at my disposal. It is a rabbit hole you never find the bottom of. Investment advisors in the business 30 years say "no one has a crystal ball"

But lots of fun.

author: j33tAy
body:
I have been to rehab three times over the last ten years. I have met people who have been twenty times.

Rehab is not a cure all or a magic place. It's an insulated, clinical, drug free environment to get clean.

However, it's not really a place to address problems.

I am drawn to all sorts of things that are high risk: self-employment, entrepreneurship, drugs, alcohol, crazy women, gambling, options and futures, racing cars, etc. 

I'm just a degenerate who has a broken dopamine cycle.

Rehab got me clean but changing my behavior was a whole different thing.

That has taken time and conscious effort on improving my discipline and priorities. I still gamble but I budget for it, for example. I don't drink because I end up going on month long benders.

I do not mean to come off as pessimistic. Getting clean and recovery are very rewarding and rehab can help. But its not what they market it to be.

Take care of yourself, homie.

author: bigpapa901
body: No sir. I owned a few shares of the stock. But it was expensive, so buying 10 shares @ $300 cost around $3000 at the time. Not enough for a stock for a gambling, bet it all, YOLO like I wanted. So, I paid roughly $6,000 for EACH option to buy 100 shares at a strike price of $290 range in 18 months (Jan 17, 2020). This was back in 2018. So I ponied up $35k to buy the options. My $35k of options became nearly worthless when the stock price hit $190. I held, and held, and held. Today I was able to buy 600 shares of Tesla at $290 while the stock price is actually $470. Somebody on the flip side of this got burned as I made out like a bandit.

Someone link to that post that shows that AMD tends to continue to rise after a big up day.

I bet you guys sat here here thinking "Don't just blindly buy calls after a +4% jump in the morning" then watched it climb another 3%.

author: geo0rgi
body:
It is crazy indeed. On one hand I am not complaining as all of my stocks are up and getting hogher almost every day. 

On the other hand though first there is nothing in this market that is fairly valued. And second this kind of run really doesn’t make much sense. 

It is really not justified by anything - revenues are stagnating, economic growth is slowing down globally, banking sector is in a weird place and we are raking up debt like there is no tomorrow. 

One thing is for certain and that is that I am really  interested to see how it all pans out. We have never been in such a situation before. My bet is that things will get ugly, but you can never know.

author: cefpodoxime
body:
1) My timeline is not wrong as I agree with you. I predict phase 3 finish by 2021 or 2022 and certainly 2023 to get to market at the earliest if approved.

2) I agree, P3 trial will likely require another offering post P3; what I meant in my post as "near future", is I don't expect another this year. but that's fine, as long as P3 results are great (see AUPH as example, with solid voclosporin results for LN last month, their offering actually caused the price to conitnue to skyrocket)

3) Yes, many many fail P3 despite positive P2 results. However, you have to actually look at the data to determine the probability of P3 clearance yourself. For example, Bitopertin from Roche tried to do similar for schizophrenia but failed in phase III, but you have to note their phase 2 results were not solid to begin with. KarXT has far more robust data in phase 2.

4) It's difficult but the FDA has been quite lenient on CNS drugs. FDA recently just approved calypta for schizophrenia (not approved for psychosis though so can't compete with KarXT at this point) from ITCI even though it had mixed results!  

5) The good thing about xanomeline is it already had phase 2 trials back in the 1990s with Eli Lilly demonstrating efficacy. It's data that added in aggregate should derisk KarXT through phase 3 too. https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6741650/pdf/CNS-9-159.pdf

author: hexydes
body:
> Not every company’s CEO is driven by this much passion of mission.

I can think of Steve Jobs and possibly Bill Gates on the same level in recent memory. Jeff Bezos and Zuckerberg on another level down (I think both are passionate for their company's success, but don't seem to have much of a grander vision). Then you get down to maybe someone like John Legere with T-Mobile, and after that, it's just a bunch of MBAs that already have one arm in their golden parachute.

Having a CEO that has laser-focus on what they want to accomplish, and the leverage within their organization to make it happen, is a very rare and powerful thing.

author: BukkakeKing69
body:
I do not understand why people believe there would be some barter economy if there is an apocalyptic scenario. Some groups would be more powerful than others and assert some level of control. The moment that organization happens you're back to using a currency. Silver/gold has been that medium of exchange for as long as currency existed up until the fiat era began about 50 years ago.

In that sense precious metals isn't about the immediate aftermath it is about retaining wealth when a new state organizes.

author: Bleak_Midwinters
body:
I think there is a better answer than "luck" that you will commonly hear. Typically you want to learn the stages of the business/economic cycle for what you are talking about. During a recession certain sectors or industries perform better, these are typically tied to what is viewed as a necessity to the consumer. An example would be utilities. 

Now, if you are asking who will survive recessions, a good indicator is the leverage ratio. How much is funded with debt compared to equity? This helps assess financial health of a company. You can look at days cash as well. This answers how many days of operations can the company fund purely off the cash on it's balance sheet. Total assets turnover or TAT can show how well the companies assets are used to produce sales. There are several others, but I think this is sufficient to send you on your path. 

During a recession you may find it easier to just pick ETFs that track underlying growth indexes and buy them at a cheap entry. Check out the performance of the Nasdaq 100 from 2009 to now. Looks tasty right? Not to say those market conditions will be replicated, but a similar strategy may be easier with lower risk than picking individual stocks. Good luck!

author: return_to_the_void
body:
This is my answer too. I did really well on picks I made during the 2008/9 recession. I had a screener set up to show me stocks that reached an all-time high in 2007 and dropped a lot through 2008 and going into 2009. I also filtered on market cap to avoid penny stocks, and a few other factors.

With the list I had, I did some research on each and tried to guess which would continue their growth during a recovery. I was focused on growth, but I know plenty of other people who were picking up dividend growth stocks on a steep discount.

My best two picks were AAPL and ISRG.

The strategy I used wouldn't have worked well during the dotcom bubble burst because many of those companies never recovered or took ~10 years to eventually recover. But because the recession was due to factors unrelated to overvalued tech (the housing bubble), I felt confident investing in tech stocks and it paid of *really fucking well* for me.

author: droidhax89
body:
As someone who works in IT I’m gonna say that’s a hard no. Look at the link that’s in the email they want you to click. I highly doubt that RH is going to ask you to download anything. So this seems phishy to me. I mean Robinhood is a pretty big company so I would think that any survey that they send you would likely have a link going directly back to them. 

Remember, anything can be hacked, even a no reply mailbox. I definitely would reach out to Robinhood support and ask. I can’t say this enough, but when it comes to something tied to financial data always be careful!
